results.title: Australyaya Gelisiminhikayesi = Coming to Australia
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Riza Guclu and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Riza Guclu moved to Australia with his family, he was looking for a better life, like most immigrants. With that in mind, he learnt what he need to help him succeed.

results.title: Kalihgat
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Terry Melvin and ACMI
results.brief_description: Terry Melvin recalls a cathartic event from his youth, when he travelled as a university student to India. In Calcutta, he worked in a hospice for the dying and destitute and tells of the experiences that have shaped and haunted the person his is today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Terry Melvin and ACMI

results.title: Italian settlement in the Yarra Valley
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Maria McCarthy and ACMI
results.brief_description: Maria McCarthy recalls the stories from her youth, the ones told about her families’ voyage from Italy to Australia and settling in the Yarra Valley. She tells of her parents’ adoption of a new culture and way of life and the legacy of those decisions on the present.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Maria McCarthy and ACMI

results.title: Foot in the air
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Laura Brearley and ACMI
results.brief_description: In Farsi, the word for transition translates as foot in the air. With one foot in the air, Laura Brearley’s life changes dramatically. The injuries she sustained have lasted throughout her life, but they are indicative of both her vulnerability and resilience. On reflection, she realises her transition was not all bad, after all.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Laura Brearley and ACMI

results.title: My ambitions
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Clune and ACMI
results.brief_description: Since David Clune first travelled to Japan at 16, he developed a thirst for travel that has never been quenched. In all his travels, he has witnessed suffering amongst the beauty and it has encouraged in him a desire to make a difference, even though he is content in Australia…for now.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Clune and ACMI

results.title: [Celebrating the Site's Flora and Fauna]
results.brief_description: Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona is an environmental wonderland, containing rare flora and fauna. Much of the original landscape has remained untouched for over 100 years. This takes us back to a time when it was formally landscaped, and representative of the early Edwardian planting of the late 1880s. Please enjoy a serene journey through the reserve, celebrating this unique ecosystem.

results.title: [The Dead Table]
results.brief_description: There’s never been any explosions at the Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona, but accidents, well that’s another story. As a child, Alan Dyall’s father worked at the reserve in Melbourne’s west. One of his many jobs involved ‘laying out in the lighters’, a lighter being a boat that carried explosives from Williamstown to the steamship. If the steamship hadn’t yet arrived, it was his job to sleep on board until it did. This is a childhood of tales lovingly recalled and the amazing story of his father’s near fatal accident.
results.description: There’s never been any explosions at the Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona, but accidents, well that’s another story. results.title: [Jim's Story]
results.brief_description: Jim Melmoth began working at the Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona at the age of 20 as part of the maintenance crew. He helped to build the extension on the pier and the water tower, which is still intact on the site today.

results.title: [The Vault]
results.creator_credit: Bronwen Gray, Bill Nicholson Jr and Alan Young
results.brief_description:
Fresh out of university, Bill Nicholson’s first professional job involved him identifying human remains located in the vault of the Melbourne Museum. Some of those remains were traced back to Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona. This animation tells the story of how these remains, discovered in Melbourne’s west, were returned to their traditional resting place.
Please note : This animation is based on a story told by Aboriginal Bill Nicholson Jr, visually interpreted by a white artist.
